entry.emph: Notice of motions — Procedure generally — Rules 18.1–18.3

row.entry: These rules require interlocutory applications in proceedings to be made by motion with notice to the other parties affected by the orders sought. The rules prescribe the formal contents of the notice and require parties to be referred to by their ordinary description in the pleadings. (ie, “plaintiff”/“(cross) defendant” as the case may be).

entry.emph: Service of notices of motion — Rules 18.4–18.5

row.entry: These rules require three days service of any notice of motion. They require personal service where the person affected is not already an active party to the proceedings.

These rules permit the court to give appropriate directions for the hearing of the motion, including its determination in the absence of a party who has been served with notice in accordance with the rules.
This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The Part substantially reproduces the former SCR Part 19, DCR Part 16 and LCR Part 15. Rule 18.3(1)(a) alters (as indicated above) the practice in relation to the description of the names of parties affected by the application (as indicated above).
Abridgment of time — liberty to apply ‥ [18.4.10]
Absence of party — disposal of motion in ‥ [r 18.7]
Interlocutory applications in Corporations Act proceedings ‥ [18.1.15]
Notice of motion — form and content ‥ [r 18.1] –[r 18.3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.1] r 18.1 Applications for court orders to be made by motion (cf SCR Part 19, rule 1; DCR Part 16, rule 1; LCR Part 15, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Applications for court orders to be made by motion (cf SCR Part 19, rule 1; DCR Part 16, rule 1; LCR Part 15, rule 1)

p.text: An interlocutory or other application is to be made by motion unless these rules otherwise provide.
The approved form is Form 20 : Notice of Motion.

This Part governs the ordinary procedure for making interlocutory or procedural applications in pending proceedings. Proper use of interlocutory procedures can clarify matters in dispute, facilitate proof, minimise surprise, reduce hearing time and costs, and procure tactical advantages. Any such application should only be made after proper consideration of the application in the circumstances of the case as a whole. Often, enquiries should first be made of the opposing party to find out whether it will consent to the interlocutory orders sought, without the need for a formal application. A party who moves the court unnecessarily, without previously seeking consent of the other party, is at risk as to costs: Moore v Gannon (1915) 32 WN(NSW) 60; Glandon Pty Ltd v Strata Consolidated Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Kirby P, No 575/88, 29 December 1988, unreported, BC8802270).

level.toc-caption: [18.1.15A] Interlocutory applications in Corporations Act proceedings

heading.title: Interlocutory applications in Corporations Act proceedings

p.text: An application under the Corporations Act in pending proceedings must be made by an interlocutory process in Form 3 of the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999; r 2.2(1), (2), (4).
In the Equity Division, motions are returnable before a registrar. Matters within a registrar's powers are dealt with at the end of the list.

In the Common Law Division, motions involving matters within a registrar's powers are made returnable before the prothonotary (registrar of the Common Law Division) on Mondays and Fridays. Matters within the prothonotary's powers are either heard on the return date (if time permits) or at a special fixture. Matters within the power of an associate judge, and ready to proceed, are referred by the prothonotary to an associate judge for hearing. Matters that are only within the power of a judge of the court are made returnable before a judge on a Monday.
Legislation cited in [18.1.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 DCR Pt 43A r 1.

In the District Court, Practice Note 1 Pt 7 (at [DC (Civil) 1] in vol 2) sets out the procedure for dealing with motions (and summonses other than costs appeals or child care appeals). (Note: Counsel are not required to robe for the hearing of Notices of Motion or Summonses). A motion will be allocated a hearing date in the general motions list on the first available Friday. The assistant registrar will deal with consent orders and adjournment applications between 9 and 9.30 on Fridays. Motions anticipated to require less than 2 hours hearing time are returnable before an assistant registrar on Fridays at 9.30 am. All motions that are ready for hearing (and some contested adjournment applications) are then referred to the judicial registrar or motions judge — either for determination or further referral to an available judge. (Note: DCR Pt 43A r 1 confers on the judicial registrar all of the powers of the District Court's ordinary civil jurisdiction.) The judicial registrar will allocate a hearing date to any notice of motion which the parties anticipate will require more than 2 hours hearing time (long motion). Long motions will generally be case managed with the substantive case and will be allocated a hearing date as soon as it is ready for hearing. All summonses (other than costs appeals or child care appeals) will be listed before the judicial registrar for case management.

The practice of listing motions in the Local Court varies according to the listing arrangements in the particular Local Court. Practitioners should make enquiries of the registrar of the court at which the motion is to be made returnable to ascertain an appropriate return date for the motion.

level.toc-caption: [18.1.15] Interlocutory applications in Corporations Act proceedings

heading.title: Interlocutory applications in Corporations Act proceedings

p.text: An application under the Corporations Act in pending proceedings must be made by an interlocutory process in Form 3 of the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999; r 2.2(1), (2), (4).
Legislation cited in [18.1.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 s 73.

The purpose of this rule is to prescribe the form in which applications in existing proceedings are to be made (namely by motion). It neither restricts nor enlarges the kind of applications that can be made in the proceedings. Whether a particular application can properly be made is to be determined according to general principles. Generally speaking, any matter arising in connection with the preparation of the proceedings, the conduct of the hearing or the enforcement of a judgment may be made by motion in the proceedings. St George Commercial Credit Corp Ltd v Wallis [2001] NSWSC 23; BC200100086 (claim to recover surplus proceeds of sale after unsuccessful challenge to mortgage and guarantees — motion appropriate). The reasoning in Wallis at [58] illustrates one instance of a permissive use of the motion procedure — as do the decisions in Roberts v Gippsland Agricultural & Earth Moving Contracting Co [1956] VLR 555; [1957] ALR 71 and Darling Downs Investments Pty Ltd v Ellwood (1988) 18 FCR 510; 80 ALR 203 (both of which dealt with enforcement of compromises by motion in the proceedings — and which is the subject of a specific power in s 73 of the CPA).

The notice of motion procedure is inappropriate where the substantive relief sought is substantially different to that which was sought in the originating process or ordered in a judgment. Haviland v McLeary (1894) 15 LR (NSW) Eq 22 at 24; 10 WN (NSW) 146c (application to remove a trustee appointed in an administration suit — motion inappropriate); Johnston v ANZ Banking Group Ltd [2003] NSWSC 454; BC200302917 at [57] (application to have party declared vexatious litigant — motion inappropriate); Re Jay-O-Bees Pty Ltd (in liq); Rosseau Pty Ltd (in liq) v Jay-O-Bees Pty Ltd (in liq) (2004) 50 ACSR 565; [2004] NSWSC 818; BC200406360 (application for rectification by motion in winding up proceedings — motion inappropriate).

The notice of motion procedure has also been held inappropriate where it would involve substantial matters beyond the ambit of the original or where the interests of justice otherwise indicate that it is desirable to institute separate proceedings: Phillips v Walsh (1990) 20 NSWLR 206 at 209, 210 (application to enforce a compromise — motion inappropriate); Spies v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1991) 24 NSWLR 691 at 697 (application to set aside consent judgment — motion inappropriate).

If an interlocutory application has been made unsuccessfully, it is generally inappropriate to make a subsequent application for the same orders. A subsequent application will almost inevitably be regarded as inappropriate, and may be regarded as an abuse of process, if there has been no material change of circumstances and the subsequent application is based on substantially the same evidence: Brimaud v Honeysett Instant Print Pty Ltd (1988) 217 ALR 44; BC8801491 ; Nominal Defendant v Manning (2000) 50 NSWLR 139; 31 MVR 524; [2000] NSWCA 80; BC200005011 ; Fletcher v Besser [2010] NSWCA 30; BC201001212 at [17] ; National Parks and Wildlife Service v Pierson (2002) 55 NSWLR 315; [2002] NSWCA 273; BC200204666 at [17] ; see also [25.1.80] .
Legislation cited in [18.1.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 36, 37.
Interlocutory orders may be varied according to the circumstances of the particular case. The relevant principles are discussed in the notes to rr 36 and 37 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.2] r 18.2 Requirement for notice (cf SCR Part 19, rule 2; DCR Part 16, rule 2; LCR Part 15, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Requirement for notice (cf SCR Part 19, rule 2; DCR Part 16, rule 2; LCR Part 15, rule 2)

p.text: A person may not move the court to make any order unless notice of motion has been filed and served on each person affected by the proposed order.
Despite subrule (1), a person may move the court to make an order without notice of motion having been filed or served on a person if:
that person consents to the making of the order, or
the preparation, filing or service of the notice would cause undue delay or other prejudice to the person by whom the order is sought, or
the court dispenses with the requirement for such notice to be filed or served, or
under these rules or the practice of the court, the motion may be made without the prior filing or service (as the case may be) of notice of motion.
Legislation cited in [18.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.2.

The notice of motion should be addressed to the parties affected by the orders sought in the notice of motion — and not to the solicitor for that party: Re Farrell (1908) 25 WN (NSW) 78; Re Baptist (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 268. The notice of motion should be served in accordance with the rules and may be served at the other parties addresses for service in the proceedings. Where there is doubt as to who should be given notice, notice should be given to all parties interested in the matter in accordance with the rules of natural justice: Re King & Co’s Trade Mark [1892] 2 Ch 462 . Any affidavits in support of a motion should be also served a reasonable time before the occasion upon which they will be used: see r 10.2 of the UCPR.
Legislation cited in [18.2.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 18.2.

UCPR r 18.2 prescribes various situations where the requirement for prior service of a notice of motion does not apply. CPA s 14 confers a further general discretion to dispense with the requirements of the rules. Generally speaking it will not be appropriate to dispense with prior service of an application unless the orders sought involve immediate urgency (and have a limited duration), involve procedural steps that are unlikely to adversely affect the interests of other parties, or are agreed between the relevant parties. Other situations where prior service requirements may be dispensed with include (i) where the person concerned is aware of the substance of the application and has taken no steps to contest it: Yeshiva Properties No 1 Pty Ltd v Lubavitch Mazal Pty Ltd (No 2) [2003] NSWSC 752; BC200304809 and (ii) where the person concerned has failed to take proper action to pursue their claims in the proceedings: Petronaitis v Rowles [2012] NSWCA 236; BC201205729 (application to strike out summons seeking leave to appeal — non-attendance by applicant aware of the orders sought).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.3] r 18.3 Contents of notice of motion (cf SCR Part 19, rule 2(4) and (5); DCR Part 16, rule 2(3) and (4); LCR Part 15, rule 2(3) and (3A))

leg:heading.title: Contents of notice of motion (cf SCR Part 19, rule 2(4) and (5); DCR Part 16, rule 2(3) and (4); LCR Part 15, rule 2(3) and (3A))

p.text: A notice of motion for an order:
must identify the person by whom the order is sought:
if the person is already a party to the proceedings, as that party (for example, as first plaintiff or second defendant), or
if the person is not yet a party to the proceedings, as the applicant, and
must identify each person affected by the order:
if that person is already a party to the proceedings, as that party (for example, as second plaintiff or first defendant), or
if that person is not yet a party to the proceedings, as the respondent, and
if the person by whom the order is sought is not already an active party, must state an address for service for that person, and
unless the motion is to be moved in the absence of the public, must state the date and time when, and the place where, the motion is to be moved, and
if the court makes an order as to the time by which the notice is to be served, must bear a note of the order made, and
must state concisely the nature of the proposed order.
[subr (1) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[30], effective 15 August 2005]

In the case of proceedings in Class 1, 2, 3 or 4 of the Land and Environment Court’s jurisdiction, a notice of motion must identify a person who is not yet a party to the proceedings by name alone, and not as the applicant or respondent as required by subrule (1)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii) .
[subr (1A) insrt Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 8 August 2008]
Costs need not be specifically claimed in the notice of motion.

If a notice of motion is of a kind that, under any Act, any rules of court or any practice of the court, is dealt with in the absence of the public, the notice of motion must contain a statement to the effect that the motion is to be so dealt with.

If it becomes necessary for an application under subrule (3) to be dealt with in court, the registrar is to refer it to the court and give notice to the parties that the application has been so referred.
The approved form is Form 20 : Notice of Motion.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.4] r 18.4 Time for service of notice (cf SCR Part 19, rule 3; DCR Part 16, rule 3; LCR Part 15, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Time for service of notice (cf SCR Part 19, rule 3; DCR Part 16, rule 3; LCR Part 15, rule 3)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a notice of motion must be served at least 3 days before the date fixed for the motion.

Although the power to abridge the time for service under this rule may be exerciseable by a registrar. The practice in some courts (notably in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court) is that the power is only exercised by a judge. In exercising this power, while the court will endeavour to make sure that cases of real urgency are dealt with quickly, it will also have regard to the interests of the affected parties and the likelihood of the application being dealt with appropriately on an accelerated return date. And it will be sensitive to the possibility that unnecessary abridgment of time may convey an undesirable element of pre-judgment contrary to the interests of the potentially affected persons. On the other hand, the court must pay proper regard to the nature of the interlocutory claim and balance the competing interests of the parties. This will require it to consider not only the actual material that is relied upon to support the application but also material that may reasonably become available in due course. Ultimately the court will, in practice, take “balance of convenience” considerations into account in determining whether to abridge the time for service: Electricity Commission of New South Wales v Arrow (NSWSC, Young J, 23 November 1990, unreported, BC9001720).

level.toc-caption: [18.4.10] Abridgment of time — liberty to apply

heading.title: Abridgment of time — liberty to apply

p.text: A grant of liberty to apply on less than three days notice operates to shorten the time for service that would otherwise be required by the rules. Where a party proposes to avail itself of that liberty, the appropriate procedure for bringing the matter back before the court is by the filing of a notice of motion in accordance with the rules: Toben v Len Sadleir Productions Pty Ltd (1993) 30 NSWLR 374; BC9304082 . However, if a party is given “liberty to restore to the list” the matter may be relisted by an appropriate request to the registry or the list clerk.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.5] r 18.5 Notice to be personally served on persons who have not entered appearance (cf SCR Part 19, rule 4; LCR Part 15, rule 2(4))

leg:heading.title: Notice to be personally served on persons who have not entered appearance (cf SCR Part 19, rule 4; LCR Part 15, rule 2(4))

p.text: A notice of motion must be personally served if the person on whom it is to be served:
is not a party to the proceedings, or
is a party to the proceedings, but is not an active party (otherwise than because the party has failed to comply with the requirements of these rules with respect to entering an appearance).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.6] r 18.6 Hearing of interlocutory applications (cf LCR Part 15, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Hearing of interlocutory applications (cf LCR Part 15, rule 5)

p.text: A party’s notice of motion in any proceedings must include, so far as practicable, all applications that the party desires to make in relation to the proceedings and that, having regard to the nature of the proceedings, can conveniently be dealt with at the one time.
On the hearing of a party’s notice of motion, any other party may make any application in relation to the proceedings.
If on the hearing of a party’s notice of motion, any other party makes an application under subrule (2), the court:
may deal with both applications at the hearing, or
may adjourn the hearing and, if appropriate, may direct any necessary notice of motion to be given to the other parties.
Legislation cited in [18.6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.2.
Evidence in chief at any interlocutory hearing must be given by affidavit, unless the court makes a contrary order: see r 31.2 of the UCPR.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.7] r 18.7 Motion may be dealt with in party’s absence (cf SCR Part 19, rule 5; DCR Part 16, rule 5; LCR Part 15, rule 5(2A))

leg:heading.title: Motion may be dealt with in party’s absence (cf SCR Part 19, rule 5; DCR Part 16, rule 5; LCR Part 15, rule 5(2A))

p.text: If service of a notice of motion on any party is required by these rules, and notice of motion has been duly served on that party, the court may hear and dispose of the motion in the absence of that party.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.8] r 18.8 Further hearing (cf SCR Part 19, rule 8)

p.text: If notice of a motion for any day has been filed or served, and the motion is not disposed of on that day:
the court may hear and dispose of the notice of motion on any later day fixed by the court, and
subject to subrule (2), filing or service of a further notice of motion is not required.
Subrule 1(b) does not apply:
if the court directs the filing or service of a further notice of motion, or
if service is required on a person on whom notice of motion has not previously been served.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 18.9] r 18.9 Directions as to conduct of proceedings on notice of motion (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6(1))

leg:heading.title: Directions as to conduct of proceedings on notice of motion (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6(1))

p.text: In proceedings on a notice of motion, the court may give directions as to the order of evidence and address and generally as to the conduct of the proceedings.
